reviews.review_text: First-rate story.  Good plot; however, it is tedious...very slow moving.  Reminds me of the TV series where Wallander appears to be a somewhat disturbed man, although one who surely fights for the right.  Sharp editing might have tightened the storyline so that things moved along more quickly.

This and the entire Wallander series by Hening Mankell is masterful. Get a list of the series in order to enjoy it more. It helps understand both the background that contributes to Wallander's life view, but gives a good sense of how he grows in his understanding of himself and others, and becomes a better detective because of it. Wonderful series.

Wallander is a frustrating detective, too frequently not taking the easier or, from the reader's perspective, more obvious path.  He would rather take the solo route with its inevitable omissions and failures, than show confidence in more regular methods.  His approach, highlighting human failures on all sides, provides for a story that is gripping, at times chilling, and leaves the reader looking forward to the next saga in the life of Wallander.

This book is a careful and clear description of the period in South Africa when Nelson Mandela was released from prison and the end of apartheid began. The history lesson is wrapped in a very compelling murder mystery. I found it a long but rewarding book, one I will not soon forget.
I enjoy most Wallander books, but this one is boring.  Kurt doesn't appear in the majority of the novel.  Just  unlikable assassins and criminal politicians with an uninteresting plot.
Full of suspence and mystery. Kurt is human who makes mistakes but doesn't give up. Loved the S Africa connection. I have learned a lot from his books.

summary:
From the dean of Scandinavian noir, the third riveting installment in the internationally bestselling and universally acclaimed Kurt Wallander series, the basis for the PBS series staring Kenneth Branagh.

The execution-style murder of a Swedish housewife looks like a simple case even though there is no obvious suspect. But then Wallander learns of a determined stalker, and soon enough, the cops catch up with him. But when his alibi turns out to be airtight, they realize that what seemed a simple crime of passion is actually far more complex—and dangerous. The search for the truth behind the killing eventually uncovers an assassination plot, and Wallander soon finds himself in a tangle with both the secret police and a ruthless foreign agent. 

Combining compelling insights into the sinister side of modern life with a riveting tale of international intrigue, The White Lioness keeps you on the knife-edge of suspense.
